text:
Raskolnikov was feeling off, like his vibe didn’t match the moment. He said, “I love those cold, dark, damp autumn evenings—like, they have to be damp—when everyone walking by looks all pale and sickly. Even better when wet snow is just falling straight down, no wind. You know what I mean?” 

The stranger he was talking to looked freaked out by the question and quickly crossed to the other side of the street. 

Raskolnikov kept walking and ended up at the Hay Market corner. He remembered this spot from when the huckster and his wife chatted with Lizaveta, but they weren’t around now. He recognized the area, paused, and asked a guy in a red shirt who was just standing there in front of a corn shop, “Isn’t there a couple that runs a booth here?”

“Yeah, lots of people have booths,” the guy replied, giving Raskolnikov a judgmental look. 

“What’s his name?” 

“Whatever he was named at birth.” 

“Are you from Zaraïsky too? Which district?” 

The young man shot Raskolnikov another glance. “It’s not a province, your excellency, it’s a district. My bad, your excellency!” 

“Is that a tavern up there?” 

“Yeah, it’s an eating-house, and there’s a billiard room. You might even spot some princesses there… La-la!” 

Raskolnikov crossed the square. In that corner, there was…

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on his surroundings and engages in a brief, awkward conversation with a stranger while searching for familiar faces in a marketplace.
